byline.original: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to prevent 50,000 cases a year of a dangerous form of hepatitis, a majority of the nation's blood banks will begin screening blood donations with two additional tests in the next few months, health officials have announced. The American Association of Blood Banks announced today that it had decided to use the tests, even though they were not precise and even though they were likely to reduce the nation's blood supply by 5 percent. ''There's a lot more public interest out there in the safety of the blood supply and we're responding to that,'' said Dr. Joseph Bove, chairman of the association's Committee on Transfusion of Transmitted Diseases.
